Authors: Suprayogi M.N., Valcke M., Godwin R.
Title: Teachers and their implementation of differentiated instruction in the classroom
Affiliations: Department of Educational Studies, Ghent University, H. Dunantlaan 2, Gent, 9000, Belgium; Department of Psychology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suprayogi, M.N., Department of Educational Studies, Ghent University, H. Dunantlaan 2, Gent, 9000, Belgium, Department of Psychology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Valcke, M., Department of Educational Studies, Ghent University, H. Dunantlaan 2, Gent, 9000, Belgium; Godwin, R., Department of Psychology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Abstract: Growing student diversity in today's classrooms calls for appropriate instructional strategies. Differentiated instruction (DI) is put forward as a key solution but seems challenging. In this study, actual DI implementation of teachers is linked to a complex set of variables: teachers' DI self-efficacy, teaching beliefs, teaching experience, professional development, teacher certification, and classroom size. The findings show that DI implementation seems high, but is still below a critical benchmark. The regression analysis results indicate 39% of the variation in DI implementation which can significantly linked to DI self-efficacy beliefs, higher constructivist beliefs and higher classroom size. Research implications are discussed. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd
Author Keywords: Differentiated instruction; Indonesia; Teachers' self-efficacy; Teaching beliefs; Teaching strategy
Funding Text 1: The authors thank to colleagues in Bina Nusantara University Indonesia for the valuable support in field data collection. This study was supported by Lotus Erasmus Mundus Action 2 project European Commission (ref.nr. Agreement Number: 2011-2584/001-001-EM Action 2-Partnerships).
